title-group.article-title: Reliability of real-time ultrasound for measuring skeletal muscle size in human limbs in vivo: a systematic review

article-meta.aff: 1International Centre for Allied Health Evidence, School of Health Sciences, University of South Australia, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Coralie English, International Centre for Allied Health Evidence, School of Health Sciences, University of South Australia, PO Box 2471 Adelaide, SA 5001, Australia Email: Coralie.english@unisa.edu.au

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To systematically review evidence for the reliability of real-time brightness-mode ultrasound for assessing skeletal muscle size in human limbs in vivo and to establish in which populations and anatomical sites the reliability had been tested.

sec.title: Data sources:
sec.p: Articles were retrieved via electronic database searching and expert contact.

sec.title: Study selection:
sec.p: Studies reporting reliability indices of test–retest measures of real-time brightness-mode ultrasound measures of skeletal muscle size within human limbs were included.

sec.title: Data extraction:
sec.p: Articles were assessed for methodological quality by two reviewers, decisions were made by consensus. Participant characteristics, measurement protocol, ultrasound protocol, type of reliability measured and statistical methods were extracted by one reviewer.

sec.title: Data synthesis:
sec.p: Twenty-four articles were included, involving 605 participants. Studies were of low to moderate methodological quality. Most studies were conducted within the healthy population. Only one study demonstrated poor reliability at one site only, and only when the participants were measured in the supine position.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: There is a moderate amount of low-level evidence that real-time brightness-mode ultrasound has good reliability for measuring muscle size across a number of limb sites in healthy populations. There is limited evidence for the reliability of ultrasound measures of muscle size in clinical populations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Loss of skeletal muscle mass is a commonly reported consequence in a number of conditions requiring rehabilitation, such as stroke1 and spinal cord injury.2 Skeletal muscle size is highly correlated with muscle function.3,4 Therefore quantifying change in skeletal muscle size may provide an indirect means of measuring muscle function and muscle recovery5 and in monitoring interventions designed to limit muscle atrophy or induce hypertrophy. This may enhance the ability to detect effective treatments and improving evidence-based practice.6

Currently computerized tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) are considered to have the highest level of accuracy and reproducibility for assessing skeletal muscle mass.7,8 However, these methods are time consuming and expensive.9 In addition, CT and DEXA expose the patient to ionizing radiation and MRI is precluded from use in persons who have pacemakers or metal implants.8 Therefore, finding an alternative to these imaging modalities is necessary if they are to be routinely used to assess skeletal muscle mass within rehabilitation populations.

Real-time brightness mode (B-mode) ultrasound may offer a useful alternative for assessing skeletal muscle size in vivo. Brightness mode ultrasound allows visualization of internal anatomy by producing a cross-sectional, grey-scale image consisting of echoes returning from tissue interfaces.10 Advantages of B-mode ultrasound are that it can be portable, is relatively inexpensive, is non-invasive and is a safe modality for use in vivo.11

The reliability of B-mode ultrasound to measure the size of trunk muscles has been extensively reviewed,12 and a recent systematic review examined evidence for the validity of ultrasound measures of skeletal muscle thickness compared to gold standard measurement tools such as CT and MRI.6 However, there is to date no published review of the evidence of the reliability of ultrasound for measurement of skeletal muscle size in human limbs in vivo.

Therefore the purpose of this review was to determine whether B-mode ultrasound is a reliable method for assessing skeletal muscle size in human limbs in vivo. In addition, this review aimed to establish in which populations and sites the reliability of B-mode ultrasound had been tested.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: Published studies investigating the reliability of measures of skeletal muscle size taken using ultrasound within human limbs were eligible for inclusion. Studies were included if they reported reliability indices of measures of real-time B-mode ultrasound measures of skeletal muscle size within human limbs. Both time and rater comparisons were acceptable. When reliability of ultrasound measures of skeletal muscle size was not the primary aim of the study, but where reliability data were available, the articles were included. A variety of muscle dimensions were acceptable and included skeletal muscle thickness or mean thickness, volume and cross-sectional measures.

Studies were excluded if limb data was unable to be extracted from the study, or other forms of ultrasound were used, such as amplitude mode (A-mode), motion mode (M-mode) or three-dimensional (3D) ultrasound.

Limitations of publication date were not imposed, nor were any restrictions placed on age, ethnicity or health status. Articles were required to be in the English language and unpublished sources were not searched.

Six electronic databases were searched including: MEDLINE, EMBASE, Allied and complementary medicine, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane and PEDro from inception to 9 October 2011. Combinations of search terms relating to skeletal muscle size and ultrasound were used (full search strategy available from the author). Where possible, the search was limited to the English language and humans.

Titles and abstracts were screened by one reviewer and those clearly not relevant were excluded. The full text of the remaining articles was independently assessed against the inclusion and exclusion criteria by two reviewers. Disagreements were resolved by consensus. The reference lists of included articles were examined for any other missed articles. The final list of articles included from the systematic search was sent to three content experts within the field for cross-checking. When included studies referred to a previous study for methodology or reliability data, the previous study was obtained and included if it met the inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Data were extracted from the included articles by one reviewer and included: participant characteristics (mean age and standard deviation, gender and health status), measurement protocol (site location, participant positioning and timeframe between measures), ultrasound protocol (technique, apparatus and measurement software or protocol) and the type of reliability measured and statistical methods used.

To determine the risk of bias within each of the studies, two reviewers independently appraised all included articles using a modified version of a published critical appraisal tool for assessing reliability studies.6 A full description of this tool is provided in the Appendix (online).

Interpretation of the reliability data presented by each study was done in accordance with recent reviews of acceptable reporting for reliability studies.13,14 Current literature suggests using more than one statistical test for interpreting reliability results.13 Studies were considered to have reported acceptable reliability if they included: (a) more than one index of reliability and (b) at least two reported indices of reliability were within the acceptable range for reliability (for example correlation coefficient of 0.6 or greater, narrow Bland Altman limits of agreement).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The inclusion and exclusion process used in the retrieval of articles is shown in Figure 1. Twenty-four articles involving a total of 605 participants were included (Table 1). The sample size within each data set ranged from 1 to 133 participants15,16 and mean ages ranged from 7 to 77 years.17,18 Seventeen studies involved healthy adult participants only, two studies involved healthy children,17,19 one involved both adults and children.20 Three trials included adults with a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis21 or neuromuscular disorders22,23 as well as healthy control participants and assessed reliability on a subsample. It was not clear whether the subsamples included controls or participants with pathology. Finally, one trial did not provide details of participants on which reliability measures were taken.24

caption.p: Flow diagram of inclusion and exclusion process used in identifying articles for the systematic review.
Summary of included articles and their general findings

Adults with inflammatory myopathies and healthy controlsa

fn.label: b
fn.p: All sites were assessed within the standing and supine position for each participant, thus producing two sets of outcome measures.

sec.p: The muscles scanned by the included studies were wide ranging, but the musculature of the leg was the most commonly assessed site (Table 1). Reliability indices were reported as acceptable across all sites, except the posterior leg measure when taken within the supine position25 (Table 2).

caption.p: Location of measurement sites and reported reliability within included studies

Between raters ICC=0.96, same image CV <1%

fn.p: r value, Pearson’s product moment correlation confident; ICC, intraclass correlation coefficient; CV, coefficient of variation; d, mean difference; CR, coefficient of repeatability.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Individual results provided for two different ultrasound machines, two different ankle joint positions and left and right sides separately.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Individual reliability data not available for each individual site assessed.

fn.label: d
fn.p: Individual results provided for individual muscles (iliopsoas, sartorius and rectus femoris, left and right).

fn.label: e
fn.p: For individual muscles (vastus lateralis, vastus medius, vastus intermedius and rectoris femoris).

sec.p: Measurement sites were determined using anatomical landmarks in all but two studies.26,27 One study re-marked the measurement site prior to retest measures being taken by transferring all anatomical landmarks onto a sheet of tracing paper to allow the exact site to be relocated prior to subsequent measures.28 All remaining studies (for which method of site location was reported) used a marking pen to define the measurement site (see Table 1). This same mark was used to identify the measurement site the test and retest measures. Ten studies did not define how the site was relocated between measures.

All but one study obtained ultrasound images using a water-based gel as a coupling agent to ensure acoustic contact between the skin and transducer. Kanehisa et al.20 used a water bath technique involving the subject’s limb being immersed in water and the operator circulating the limb with the transducer head. The muscle dimension measured varied between studies and included mean muscle thickness, linear muscle thickness, cross-sectional area and volume.

Both intra-rater and inter-rater reliability was assessed. In nine studies it was not possible to determine whether intra- or inter-rater reliability had been assessed.15,16,20,21,26,27,29–31 The difference between same day and separate day reliability was also assessed within five studies.15,17,28–30

The statistical measures used to assess reliability were varied among studies (see Table 2). The intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) was the most commonly reported reliability statistic, however only seven studies reported associated 95% confidence intervals.17,23,25,28,30,32,33 Reported ICC values were generally high and were reported as greater than 0.70, except the posterior leg in one study.25 Coefficients of variance were reported in eight studies and were generally low arranging from 1.2 to 7.4%.15–18,22–23,29,34 Correlations of repeatability, typical error of measurement and Bland–Altman analyses (including mean differences) were reported infrequently, yet all indicated low measurement variability. Fifteen studies reported more than one statistical test.

The studies included within this review were varied in their methodological rigour but in general the studies were of a low to moderate level of methodological quality (Table 3). All studies used an appropriate test–retest design to assess reliability of the ultrasound measures, yet reliability was not the primary aim in 12 studies. Sources of bias that were poorly controlled or not reported by the majority of studies included lack of assessor blinding, selection of participants, selection of statistical techniques and specifying the timeframe between measures. The majority of studies standardized the participant position, defined the scanning point, used appropriate image acquisition frequencies and described the equipment used.

caption.p: Assessment of risk of bias within studies included within the systematic review

fn.p: 1. Focused study aim, 2. blind assessor, 3. bias in selection, 4. appropriate statistical analysis, 5. timeframe between measures reported, 6. muscle state, 7. participant starting position, 8. scanning point, 9. contact pressure, 10. transducer position, 11. appropriate image acquisition, 12. type of equipment adequately described, 13. confidence intervals.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of this review suggest that ultrasound measures of muscle size taken in healthy participants are reliable. Reliability indices were similar for intra-rater, inter-rater, same-day and separate-day measures and were relatively similar across all sites and populations. However, these results should be considered in light of the methodological limitations of many of the studies which may have led to overestimation of reliability indices.

It is important that judgements regarding the reliability of a measure are not made on the basis of a single reliability index.13,14 Most of the articles in this review reported only a measure of correlation such as the ICC or Pearson’s r statistic. Such statistics can be misleading as it is possible to have a high correlation between scores, but large measurement error35 and conversely values that are homogeneous can lead to low correlation scores.13 Furthermore, a reported ICC scores may have a very wide associated confidence interval, particularly if the sample size used to calculate the score was very small. Confidence intervals for ICCs were only reported in seven studies17,24,25,28,30,32,33 which creates further difficulties in accepting the reported results.

In addition to the potential overestimation of reliability arising from inadequate statistical analyses, other sources of bias within the included studies further limit the confidence with which results can be interpreted. First, only four studies within this review blinded the assessor.21,25,28,33 This is a potentially large source of bias due to the potential for assessors to recall measurements previously obtained. Second, 12 studies within this review conducted reliability analyses of ultrasound measures as part of a larger study in which reliability was not the primary aim. In these cases only scant details were provided regarding the methodology used, and in many cases key details, such as whether one or more raters obtained measures, or the timeframe between measurement occasions, were not clear. Finally, with one exception,28 all studies either reported that the ultrasound transducer was placed on the exact same (marked) site on the skin for repeat measures, or did not provide details about relocating the measurement site for repeat measures. If ultrasound is to be used as an outcome measure to assess changes over time or the effect of an intervention, then relocation of the measurement site must be part of any reliability assessment.

There were four studies within this review that had a low risk of bias,17,25,28,36 conducted comprehensive statistical analyses and included assessor blinding. All of these studies reported high test–retest reliability across the majority of sites assessed, however a greater degree of measurement variability was evident within the study conducted by Thoirs and English25 and one site (posterior lower leg) had poor reliability.

Importantly, no studies were identified in this review which investigated measurement of muscle size in pathological or hospitalized populations. The possible exceptions being three studies that included participants with rheumatoid arthritis21 or neuromuscular disorders22,23 and aged-matched controls. However, reliability was assessed on subsamples only and it was not clear whether these subsamples included participants with pathology or healthy controls. Imaging of diseased or deconditioned muscle has a number of typical differences compared to healthy muscle which may lead to greater difficulty in obtaining reliable results. In particular, increased echogenicity, loss of bone edge definition, shadowing and blurring of the demarcations between fibrous tissue and the muscle5 may make it more difficult to confidently obtain images of skeletal muscle size within pathological or deconditioned populations. Therefore, the effects of age and health status on the reliability of measures of skeletal muscle thickness remain unknown. A greater number of studies in older adults, children and pathological populations are warranted.

This review employed a comprehensive and broad search strategy which included cross-referencing with content experts to identify any missed articles. However, as only English language papers were included and no sources of grey (unpublished) literature were searched, some papers may have been missed.

list-item.p: Ultrasound measures of muscle size taken from healthy people are probably reliable, but more high-quality studies are required to confirm this.
There is currently no evidence regarding the reliability of ultrasound measures of muscle size taken from people in hospital or with disease states.

ack.p: The authors would like to gratefully acknowledge Jenny Keating Professor, Head of Physiotherapy, School of Primary Health Care, Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences, Monash University for the provision and advice in modifications of CAT and advice regarding this paper.
